title: Sick of seeing Christmas decorations before Halloween? Blame 40% of America
text:
CLOSE Why are Christmas decorations put up so early? Wochit, Wochit

LOUISVILLE, Ky. – Frost hasn't yet settled on the pumpkins on your porch, but that hasn't stopped hordes of shoppers from getting a jump start on purchasing gifts for the winter holidays.

Roughly 40% of consumers begin their holiday shopping before Halloween, according to the National Retail Federation's2019 holiday forecast. Further, a full 19% are "early bird" shoppers who started in September or earlier.

That's because people want to "spread out their spending," says Katherine Cullen, senior director of consumer and industry insights for the federation. Cullen added that early shopping has been a consistent trend for the past 15 years or so.

Not only are shoppers starting earlier, but they're spending more, too. The National Retail Federation predicts holiday retail sales during November and December will increase by about 4% over 2018 to a total of around $730 billion.

Sooner than you think: Why you should start saving for the holiday season now

So whether you like it or not, the holiday shopping season is upon us. Here's everything you should know ahead of the 2019 holiday shopping season:

Why do so many people shop early?

There's a couple of reasons why people choose to shop for the holidays months in advance. For starters, some customers think they are "going to see ...deals and promotions all season long," so they choose to shop early for some stores and later for others, Cullen said.

Another reason people hit the stores early is to avoid the frenzy of shoppers. Holiday sales are tallied by the National Retail Federation from Nov. 1 to Dec. 31 – a high-volume shopping period nationwide.

For those who choose to shop early, they may be trying to "get away from crowds and hectic shopping environments," Cullen told The Courier Journal.

Should you spread out your shopping or do it all at once?

Christmas and Halloween shopping side-by-side in many stores this season including At Home in Jeffersontown. Oct. 29, 2019 (Photo: Alton Strupp/Courier Journal )

There is no one way to correctly shop, Cullen said, so shopping earlier or later is really a personal preference. Even those who come into the season most prepared, and start shopping months in advance, might still be getting some last-minute gifts in December.

But, for Cullen, one thing is clear: stay alert.

"Being an informed shopper goes a long way," she said. "It’s definitely worth watching what retailers are doing throughout the season."

More specifically, Cullen said shoppers should pay attention to retailers' catalogs and websites for holiday sales and promotions.

How do local stores deal with earlier shoppers?

To deal with an increased volume of shoppers, retailers will hire between 530,000 and 590,000 temporary workers during the 2019 holiday season, according to a National Retail Federation estimate.

According to Cullen, retailers have "gotten a head start on holiday hiring" due to the early-bird shoppers – with some choosing to keep employees they hired for the back-to-school season.

So if you're looking for seasonal holiday employment, now is the right time to start.

How much will people spend this year?

Holiday retail sales are expected to increase between 3.8% and 4.2% over 2018 to a total of between $727.9 billion and $730.7 billion, according to the National Retail Federation's forecast of holiday sales.

More specifically, consumers say they will spend an average of $1,047.83 this holiday season, up 4% from the $1,007.24 of 2018.

Cullen said he overall economic health and the absence of a government shutdown, which plagued the 2018 shopping season, will contribute to this increase in spending.

Due to shutdown fears over tariffs and market volatility, holiday sales only grew 2.1% in 2018 from the year before, which was an abnormally small increase, according to the NRF. That was less than half the 5.2% growth seen during the 2017 holiday season.

“All of that uncertainty can make consumers a little bit shy about spending that extra money," Cullen said. "They want to make sure they have a great holiday season, but they don’t want to overspend and break their budget.”

What are people spending money on this holiday season?

Of the $1,048 the average person will spend during the 2019 holiday shopping season, $659 of that will be spent on gifts for family, friends or co-workers, according to the National Retail Federation report.

About $227 will be spent on non-gift holiday items such as food and decorations and $162 will be spent on other non-gift purchases for family or self, according to the report.

Men are projected to spend more at $1,152.17, while women will spend closer to $948.90 this holiday shopping season.

Additionally, the biggest spenders are shoppers age 35 to 44 at an average of $1,158.63, just narrowly ahead of the average $1,157.95 that shoppers ages 45 to 54 will spend in 2019, according to the report.

And if you're wondering where pocketbooks are deepest, shoppers in the Northeast will spend $1,178.96 on average. Shoppers in the South will spend $1,027.80.

Where will people do their holiday shopping?

Online shopping comes out on top, with 56% of consumers saying they'll shop online in 2019. The National Retail Federation estimates online and other non-store sales to increase between 11% and 14% to between $162.6 billion and $166.9 billion this season.

But fear not: the era of the big-box store is not completely over. Though 56% of holiday shoppers say they will shop online, 53% say they will also shop in department stores, along with 51% at discount stores and 44% at grocery stores/supermarkets.

Of online shoppers, a full 73% said they plan to use their smartphone or tablet to research or make a purchase. Roughly one-third of consumers say they'll also shop at clothing or accessory stores, and 23% say they'll shop at local/small businesses and at electronic stores.

“People are spreading out their shopping across different destinations," Cullen said. "They don’t necessarily distinguish between in-store and online."
